title: Thursday, 6th July, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:00 am
PM11:00am

PM11:01am

PM11:03am

So slow

PM11:03am

Anyway, FOMC minutes last night

11:03 am
PM11:03am

I had expected more of a reaction

PM11:03am

It's really happening

PM11:03am

End of an era

11:03 am
PM11:03am

But yeah, everyone was primed

PM11:04am

(Jeez -- Windows...)

PM11:04am

What a slab of grey on this?

11:04 am
PM11:05am

Have Michael Gapen of Barclays

PM11:05am

Much of the information contained in the minutes to the June FOMC meeting were already known to markets given the release of the June FOMC statement, press conference materials, and question and answer session last month. That said, we were interested to receive information on two topics to which the minutes could rightly speak: namely, how concerned were FOMC members about the recent softness in inflation and when might the committee make a formal announcement on the timing of a change in its balance sheet reinvestment policy. On these fronts, we interpret the minutes to be in line with our baseline outlook. We continue to expect a formal announcement to change the reinvestment policy at the September meeting, followed by a third rate increase this year in December as most FOMC members see recent softness in inflation as driven by idiosyncratic factors.

PM11:05am

A change in balance sheet reinvestment policy: not too soon and not too late. The minutes indicate that FOMC participants expressed a “range of views about the appropriate timing of a change in reinvestment policy.” Taken on its face, this means that the committee has not yet reached consensus about the appropriate timing of any announcement. This is consistent with Chair Yellen’s comments in the press conference that no decision on timing had been made. The minutes indicate that “several” participants preferred to start the process “within a couple of months” while “some others” said that “deferring the decision until later in the year would permit additional time to assess the outlook for activity and inflation.” “A few” of these participants (who preferred to begin balance sheet runoff later) said moving too soon might give the market the impression that the Fed policy had turned more hawkish than was intended. In our view, the minutes suggest that only several committee members pushed for an announcement at the July meeting since “within a couple of months”, if read literally, indicates inside of two months.

11:05 am
PM11:05am

What is less clear to us is when the remainder of the committee prefers to make the formal announcement on balance sheet policy. In our view, waiting “until later in the year” to better assess the outlook for activity and inflation could take until December (or later in the case of inflation), but deferring a decision on the balance sheet this long would be, in our view, inconsistent with what the chair mentioned in her press conference. During the question and answer session, Chair Yellen responded to a question on upcoming Fed policy decisions by saying the committee “could put this [a change in balance sheet policy] into effect relatively soon.” Hence, we read the minutes and the other Fed communication at the time of the June meeting as pointing to September as the most likely time for an announcement on a change in balance sheet reinvestment policies. An announcement in July, which would leave open the possibility of rate hikes in both September and December, could generate adverse market movements, while waiting until December may be viewed as waiting too long in an environment where the unemployment rate continues to fall further than most committee members expected. “Relatively soon”, in our view, does not sound like July and it does not sound like December.

PM11:05am

One more block

PM11:06am

Idiosyncratic factors drive underperformance in inflation. On the subject of inflation, the minutes were quite clear and in line with our expectation. How the minutes would characterize recent inflation performance was answered quite quickly. The minutes to the June FOMC meeting went so far as to note that, in addition to being a useful predictor of future inflation, core inflation “can be affected by transitory factors.” With the May information in hand at the time of the meeting, “most participants” felt that softness in inflation was driven by “idiosyncratic factors, including sharp declines in prices of wireless telephone services and prescriptions drugs” and would have “little bearing on inflation over the medium term.” In the press conference, Chair Yellen said these base effects would likely weigh on y/y rates of inflation through March of next year. Only “several” participants expressed “concern” in the minutes that recent softness in inflation “might persist.” Others countered this opinion by saying that too much labor market tightness could push inflation risks in the other direction. Altogether, we read the state of the discussion to say that the majority of the committee does not view inflation underperformance as warranting a change in the Fed’s normalization stance. Nor is it likely that weakness in inflation through year-end (on a year-on-year basis) would be enough to deter a rate hike in December, given the chair’s expectation that base effects will persist into Q1. Any delay in the Fed’s normalization plans from below-target inflation may not be forthcoming until early next year.

11:06 am
PM11:06am

So yeah, everything as expected

PM11:06am

But still the end of the ZIRP era

PM11:06am

Except we have still got Japan and the ECB (for now)

11:06 am
undefined

11:07 am

We're down-ish, which we can blame on various things other than the FOMC.

FTSE off 0.7% at 7318, partly on ex divs and stuff.

BE11:08am

Being led down by Worldpay again.

11:08 am
Worldpay Group PLC (WPG:LSE): Last: 362.28, down 9.72 (-2.61%), High: 370.40, Low: 361.60, Volume: 5.38m
PM11:08am

(Eikon up! 17 mins from 'restart' )

BE11:08am

And wasn't this fun!

11:08 am
BE11:08am

To recap ...... as talked about, there was a friendly and mutually beneficial Vantiv offer, funded mostly in scrip.

PM11:08am

Fun for some

BE11:09am

That formally started the auction process. And some what unexpectedly it started the process at an easy to clear 19% premium.

11:09 am
BE11:09am

Then, half an hour later, that auction process ended.

BE11:09am

JPM folded immediately.

BE11:09am

Which took out most of the merger arb community, who've had a rather tricky week. It's not often you get stretchered out on a position you've only held for one day.

11:09 am
PM11:10am

hehehehe

BE11:10am

Hardly any sellside have published this morning either, incidentally.

BE11:10am

I guess they tired themselves out with all that multiple party bidding war up to 500p stuff we spent 30 minutes on yesterday.

11:10 am
BE11:10am

Takes some time to reverse ferret from there.

BE11:10am

Have some KBW.

BE11:10am

[385p] represents about 26x our 2018 EPS estimate for WPG of £0.15, but closer to 13x adjusted for our estimate potential cost and revenue synergies of $300 million. On an EV/EBITDA basis, it would equate to 14x (10x adjusted for synergies) our 2018 WPG estimates. Excluding the dividend, this represents a premium of about 18.9% to Worldpay’s closing price on July 3. Following the completion of the potential merger, Worldpay shareholders would own about 41% of the share capital of the combined group on a fully diluted basis.

11:10 am
BE11:10am

According to a [WSJ] article, WPG had been holding informal discussions with potential suitors for months so it’s hard to see how another party comes in at this stage in the game to outbid VNTV’s offer. While Worldpay could be an attractive asset for other players such as PayPal (primarily the gateway piece), we believe that the combination of VNTV and WPG is a better strategic fit given the complementary business lines across the US, UK, and eCom. We would note that VNTV's announced offer is preliminary and the company has until August 1, 2017, to make a final bid (although this date could be extended). The offer period will remain open up until the deal closes.

BE11:11am

(The WSJ article referred to is here: http://news.mornin...ay-4th-update.aspx )

PM11:11am

What was the roughly undisturbed price of this thing?

11:11 am
PM11:11am

Around 320p?

BE11:11am

Depends what we consider undisturbed, which leads us down another path.

PM11:12am

Down which we are not going to go

11:12 am
BE11:12am

Well, let's just nod at it.

BE11:13am

Yesterday's statement referred to "A premium of approximately 20.7% to the closing Worldpay Share price on 30 June 2017, the day prior to broad sector consolidation speculation;"

BE11:13am

Which I guess is fair enough post the Nets bid.

11:13 am
BE11:13am

But running parallel to that is an idea getting pushed right now that the Worldpay rumour was around on Monday

BE11:14am

Causing a spike in Worldpay volume that the regular press didn't pick up, because we're rubbish at our jobs.

BE11:14am

Thing is, it's simply not true.

11:14 am
BE11:14am

Here's Worldpay total daily volume across all European exchanges (Bloomberg data).

BE11:14am

BE11:14am

Monday's volume was in fact slightly below the 30-day rolling average. About 12m traded, most of which was of course the LSE.

11:14 am
BE11:14am

There's nothing interesting whatsoever about that data.

BE11:14am

LSE volume was totally normal, other exchange volumes were totally normal, market share across exchanges was totally normal.

BE11:14am

And it's not as if volume was elevated in the run-in either. Same chart since the start of the year.

11:14 am
BE11:14am

BE11:15am

Okay, so why is any of this important?

PM11:15am

Go on

11:15 am
BE11:16am

Well ... I have to be careful what I say here. But why would someone want to encourage the idea that the Worldpay rumour was around the market on Monday, when all the evidence points to that being untrue?

BE11:16am

In my experience, that kind of thing tends to suggest that a person who might have been less careful than expected with information is now worried about their collar being felt.

BE11:16am

And, of course, yesterday's events invite quite a lot of speculation about who leaked what and why.

11:16 am
PM11:17am

I think you might be right

BE11:17am

As in, JP Morgan claiming via an RNS they were approached by Worldpay and had only just started work on the idea when it leaked.

BE11:17am

While people familiar with the thinking in the Worldpay camp seem to have a rather different recollection of how things happened.

11:17 am
BE11:17am

There's a lot of rainmaker strategy in all this, and it's beyond our remit here. Suffice to say, the tick-tocks will be fascinating, when they land.

PM11:17am

So we assume there's a full stewards underway no on this

BE11:18am

Well ..... It would be a surprise if that weren't the case.

11:18 am
BE11:18am

And sorry to talk shop for a moment, but it does take me back to what we were talking about on Tuesday with regards double independent sourcing and all that junk. https://ftalphavil...tslive/2017-07-04/

BE11:18am

Part of that whole protocol is for the protection of sources.

BE11:18am

If we were to publish the first thing we heard from the first person we heard it, it's not going to be overly difficult to work out where that information has come from. It risks leaving people we trust to speak in confidence feeling exposed, and makes everyone's life more difficult.

11:18 am
BE11:18am

But anyway, that's enough of that.

BE11:19am

Good luck to the rumour aggregators. And good luck to those who talk to them.

undefined

PM11:19am

BE11:21am

BE11:22am

Which is unlikely to have trading news, given its results were a month ago. Anyway, we have no new information on Aveva worth sharing other than to note it's on everyone's watchlist, and has been for about a month.

undefined
11:00 am
PM11:01am

Welcome to Markets Live

BE11:24am

After being speculated for approximately as long as any of our lifetimes, Novae becomes the latest Lloyds insurer to be taken out.

BE11:24am

Axis the buyer. Announcement at 10.30pm last night, for no apparent reason other than to mess with our lives.

11:25 am
PM11:25am

Presumably that announcement in response to a checking call from a journalist...

PM11:25am

(But leads us back down that path we didn't want to go)

BE11:25am

Possibly, I guess, but didn't look that way.

11:25 am
PM11:26am

(tl;dr -- if regulation forces companies to screw over journalists checking stories, the result will be unchecked stories getting published...)

BE11:26am

Anyway, price looks reasonable rather than generous.

BE11:26am

Here's Peel Hunt.

11:26 am
BE11:26am

AXIS, a leading Bermudian (re)insurer, has announced it is
acquiring Novae for 700p per share in cash equivalent to 1.4x our
2017e TNAV (1.5x fully diluted). The deal offers a compelling
strategic rationale and allows AXIS to strengthen its position
within Lloyd’s. It also allows Novae to continue to invest and
grow its Lloyd’s specialty insurance business backed by a strong
capital base. The deal creates a diversified Top 10 specialty
insurer within Lloyd’s and is financially attractive for AXIS,
providing both top-line growth and cost synergies. The purchase
price offers a 20% premium to NVA shareholders at a multiple
(1.4x P/TNAV vs NVA 1.2x at yesterday’s close) that seems
justified given the transition the company is going through and
the returns we expect the company to generate in the next few
years, and it is c5% above our TP. We believe the deal should be
welcomed as AXIS provides deal certainty and offers Novae the
opportunity to continue its growth strategy where it is
complementary to AXIS.

BE11:27am

The multiple to TNAV compares to an average 1.4x TNAV (1.5x fully diluted) paid for Bermudian insurers and 1.6x on average for Lloyd’s insurers (excluding the MS Amlin deal). We believe the multiple is justified given the return outlook for NVA from 2018 onwards in soft market conditions.

BE11:27am

The combination of AXIS ($5bn premiums) and Novae ($1.2bn premium income) lifts AXIS into the Top 10 insurers at Lloyd’s with a combined premium volume of $1.5bn within Lloyd’s and a total group premium income of $6.2bn. It accelerates AXIS’s international growth plans and allows for further investment in Novae’s strategy to build out its ‘invest underwriting classes’. It also shifts AXIS business mix away from reinsurance (currently 45% of GWP) towards specialty lines with Novae’s portfolio providing many new underwriting classes and a complementary book in other areas. Hence, there seems to be minimal overlap and a solid strategic rationale to expand the Lloyd’s specialty operations. AXIS highlights the deal will create meaningful top-line synergies and $50m of pre-tax cost synergies. AXIS states the transaction is accretive to EPS in year 1 excluding synergies, sees high single digit accretion in year 2, is accretive to operating RoE and has a minimal impact on AXIS TNAV. We estimate the initial RoI on the deal, excluding synergies, is 7.5% assuming £35m of Novae 2018e net profit and 11% RoI in year 2. Hence the deal looks attractive for AXIS shareholders providing deal certainty.

11:27 am
BE11:28am

And KBW from the perspective of the buyer.

BE11:28am

Although there’s definitely some scarcity value to the few remaining Lloyd’s insurers, the price seems a little high to us given Novae’s May 10, 2017, guidance of a 2017 underwriting loss and a 97-98% 2018 combined ratio. We'd previously viewed AXIS more as a buyer than a seller, and this announcement makes a sale of AXIS even less likely, which should remove most of any takeout premium embedded in the shares. (It does make a bigger and riskier transformative deal less likely.) Second, we think this deal makes strategic sense for AXIS – specialty insurers are increasingly competing on the bases of scale and diversification – although persistently adverse pricing (Novae reported an overall 2% decrease in May) will probably exacerbate the employee distraction and premium spillage risks inherent in almost all P&C M&A.

BE11:28am

So ........ who's left?

11:28 am
Lancashire Holdings Ltd (LRE:LSE): Last: 736.50, up 26 (+3.66%), High: 741.00, Low: 716.50, Volume: 256.74k
Beazley PLC (BEZ:LSE): Last: 511.85, up 6.85 (+1.36%), High: 515.50, Low: 502.50, Volume: 457.75k
Hiscox Ltd (HSX:LSE): Last: 1,291, up 9 (+0.70%), High: 1,294, Low: 1,279, Volume: 93.96k
11:30 am
BE11:31am

BE11:31am

Are there any others?

PM11:31am

There's enough to be getting on with

11:32 am
BE11:32am

Note, by the way, that Neptune (15% holder) is on the wires arguing that it wants more money.

BE11:32am

(Well, yes. Of course it does.)

BE11:33am

Note also that it's post Novae's profit warning in December so could plausibly be seen as opportunistic if you ignore the reasons for that profit warning and the rebasing of forecasts that followed.

11:34 am
BE11:34am

Still, perhaps Neptune can cause trouble here. Wouldn't be wildly surprised to see the likes of Elliot get involved either, given this is their kind of position.

undefined
PM11:34am

FJP and others asking for AB Foods

11:34 am
PM11:35am

Top of the Footsie gainers list

PM11:35am

Thanks to Primark

Associated British Foods plc (ABF:LSE): Last: 3,015, up 93 (+3.18%), High: 3,102, Low: 2,975, Volume: 693.32k
11:35 am
BE11:35am

Yep, Primark's back! Q3 sales bounce.

PM11:35am

Trading up date here https://www.invest...1707060700032325K/

BE11:35am

Perhaps they stuck an extra person on the tills.

11:35 am
PM11:36am

GBK helped a tad, i think

BE11:36am

Primark dollar sourcing costs are huge, of course, because of its high volume fast chain model.

BE11:36am

FY guidance is reassuring rather than hugely positive.

11:37 am
BE11:37am

If you were previously worried about Primark's weakening sales densities and new store cannibalisation and etc, this has probably eased your worries a tad. Here's Barclays.

BE11:38am

ABF’s update (16 weeks to 24 June) should offer much reassurance on Primark UK in the context of a soft clothing market, while the FX related margin decline now looks well underpinned. The soft spot is UK bread, while the Sugar recovery story is unchanged. Our estimates are raised 1-2% with our price target accordingly. Lingering uncertainty around the UK high street hasn’t disappeared, nor concerns over an absence of an e-commerce strategy. However, after the challenges of 2016, momentum at the group in aggregate looks to be gently improving. We expect the shares to continue to recover, with our PT implying a value for Primark in line with Inditex vs the current 13% discount (and vs the 40% premium from 18 months ago).

BE11:38am

We estimate LFL growth for Primark in Q2 was up c.2%, compared with flat in H1. This was helped by an easy comparable period, but also what looks to have been a pickup in momentum at Primark UK. The model continues to benefit from the strength, breadth and value of its range in an otherwise soft clothing environment. Total YTD Primark UK sales are said to be up 9%, suggesting growth in Q3 of over 12%, with LFL’s thereby up an estimated 5-7% (up from +2% H1). Although, trading on the continent looks to still be negative, we estimate Q3 saw some improvement on the -2% LFL seen in H1. At the same time, greater cost mitigation benefits from its buying and merchandising teams, lower mark downs (and we assume UK leverage) has led the group to now expect a smaller FX transaction related margin decline for the year.

11:38 am
BE11:39am

And Jefferies.

BE11:39am

The combination of a strengthened value leadership, a more defensively minded UK consumer and improvements in the overall fashion content in S/S 2017 are all contributing factors behind Primark's accelerating industry outperformance. UK sales gains of +9% YTD are a testament to that. In addition, new space productivity remains excellent internationally. Indeed, our recent visits to stores in Italy and Spain highlight the strong differentiation that Primark benefits from relative to local competition, as well as the considerable scope for future openings. The key upcoming driver for continued stock outperformance should be a recovery in Primark margins (we expect close to 100bps between 16/17 and 18/19) supporting mid-term EBIT CAGR of greater than 16% at this division. And with H2 Primark margin guidance improved today from a previous 'worse than -170bps' to -170bps, the switch from forecast headwind to tailwind is already materialising. Click here for a more in-depth discussion from us on how competitors' recent lifting of price points should pave the way for Primark price recovery from A/W 2017.

BE11:40am

We see more multiples expansion from here, as we estimate Primark currently trading on c.25x, a valuation context that can be further improved on in light of strong double-digit EBIT growth prospects. And in turn ABF attracts given a three-year EPS CAGR of greater than 13%, FC of £800m by 18/19 and lease adj net debt/EBITDAR of sub 1x already from this year.

11:40 am
PM11:40am

So on the grocery side they are blaming bakery costs for a squeeze on margins

PM11:40am

This is wheat, right?

PM11:40am

We know about the wheat spike

11:40 am
PM11:41am

But Paul Moran round at Northern Trust also talking about butter prices

PM11:41am

I hadn't noticed this -- tho I am one of those people who believes butter is better for you than marg

PM11:41am

Oh my

11:41 am
PM11:41am

PM11:41am

117% year on year!

PM11:42am

11:42 am
PM11:42am

This is from a (sell) note on Aryzta

PM11:42am

Who are Aryzta? Omg smile

PM11:42am

In an otherwise positive update, AB Foods highlighted how in the U.K., “the bread market has remained very competitive which, combined with inflationary cost pressures in bakery, has had a negative impact on Grocery margins.”

We think the primary driver here is wheat costs, which have spiked. But it’s not just wheat that will be an issue for Aryzta, croissants, cheese sticks and cookies require a lot of butter. Butter prices have been rising, as a combination of lack of supply and a resurgence in butter demand (we think you blame cooking TV shows and the switch from margarine and other spreads to butter).

11:42 am
PM11:43am

These are price rises that will be a struggle for Aryzta to pass on we think given the challenges it has been facing in the last 6-12 months. Sell Aryzta.

PM11:43am

Hmm

PM11:43am

Aryzta used to be..

11:43 am
PM11:43am

The company was founded as the Irish Co-Operative Agricultural Agency Society in January 1897

PM11:43am

Listed in Dublin and Zurich

BE11:43am

Also the number one frozen bakery supplier in Europe, according to its website.

11:43 am
PM11:43am

Learn something every day on here

BE11:44am

Why on earth would you want frozen bakery? Every day, civilised society erodes just a little more.

PM11:44am

Aryzta down 3% in Surich

11:44 am
PM11:44am

So the market's with you on that Bryce

PM11:45am

Zurich not Surich

undefined
11:45 am
PM11:45am

Do you think we'll bet butter riots?

PM11:45am

(Sorry)

PM11:46am

What else?

11:46 am
BE11:46am

Um .......... I think we could stick to consumer goods, since we seem to have drifted into that cul de sac.

Reckitt Benckiser Group PLC (RB.:LSE): Last: 7,524, down 176 (-2.29%), High: 7,647, Low: 7,451, Volume: 1.79m
BE11:47am

Sales warning, mild and entirely one-off in nature, so no one really cares.

11:47 am
PM11:47am

To be fair -- they did openly say on the day of the attack that it had affected invoicing etc etc

PM11:48am

This really shouldnt have come as a surprise

BE11:48am

Yup. They'd flagged up the bit about them damn haxx0rz, with their ransomwares and whatnot.

11:48 am
BE11:48am

Though Reckitt's a bit vulnerable to this stuff generally.

BE11:49am

You'll remember the supply chain going wrong last year too.

BE11:49am

Korea, if I remember correctly.

11:49 am
BE11:49am

Also the failed launch of something called Scholl Wet & Dry.

BE11:50am

And they seemed to suffer more than the rest from India's demonetisation, for reasons I was never totally clear about.

BE11:50am

Let me cut to UBS to summarise its latest laundry list of operational failings.

11:51 am
BE11:51am

RB has announced this morning that the cyber-attack on 27 June has disrupted its "ability to manufacture and distribute products to customers in multiple markets"; and RB was unable to ship and invoice some orders in the last week of Q2 (but MJN business was not impacted). Some of RB's factories are still not operating normally. Separately, the implementation of GST in India resulted in reduced orders from some customers during June. As a consequence, RB is estimating that its Q2 organic sales growth will be -2% (rather than flat, excluding the impact of the cyber-attack). While RB expects to recover some of the lost revenue in Q3, it does expect some permanent losses – we think this is because some factories are not functioning normally and RB will cede market share as it cannot supply for promotional slots at some retailers. RB has lowered its 2017 organic sales guidance from +3% to +2%

BE11:51am

All else unchanged, we estimate the impact of the guidance cut to consensus EPS is around -1% (although this might get worse if margins come under pressure). However, we expect the stock to de-rate on this news because: (1) the guidance cut implies that RB had very little slack around its +3% target and all it took was another one-off for management to lower it. Instead, the latest consensus estimates (from Q1) of +3.4% imply that market was expecting RB to comfortably deliver +3%; and (2) RB is dealing with four 'one-offs' now: Scholl de-stocking, South Korea fall-out, India GST and cyber- attack. This could create some discomfort around RB's controls, in our view.

BE11:53am

Look, I dunno. It would be wrong so consider any of this stuff as symptomatic of a broader problem. But when you run a company where management is obsessed with costs, it tends to leave not much slack for things to go wrong.

11:53 am
BE11:54am

Reckitt seems to suffer quite a bit from things going wrong. Might be a cultural problem, in which case it should probably be in forecasts. Might just be luck, in which case it shouldn't.

BE11:54am

Here's MOST.

BE11:54am

By 2020, RB should be one of the fastest growing names in Global Staples, with superior returns and cash generation, in our view. We believe the real prize for both investors and RB management, is not optical topline acceleration in 2H17-1H18, nor mechanical accretion from the Mead deal but RB 2020: structural growth on high margins, with a balance sheet ready to be deployed again. Near-term concerns on topline growth present a standout opportunity, we believe. We see any weakness in share price performance on lower guidance and weaker 2Q LFL as an attractive opportunity to buy "RB 2020".

11:54 am
PM11:54am

(Blue horseshoe... read earlier)

undefined
BE11:55am

Otherwise ............

11:55 am
BE11:55am

...... there's Smurfit. One of the regulars on the right is usually keen on paper, aren't they? I forget who.

Smurfit Kappa Group PLC (SKG:LSE): Last: 2,333, down 68 (-2.83%), High: 2,375, Low: 2,326, Volume: 215.50k
BE11:56am

Big note out of Goldman.

11:56 am
BE11:56am

Signs of pulp weakness emerging

BE11:57am

Pulp prices have rallied more than we expected ytd,
with hardwood up 28% and softwood up 10%,
driven by supply delays, inventory restocking and
solid demand. We now see emerging signs of pulp
price weakness and expect a supply ramp-up to
weigh on near-term pulp prices for both hardwood
and softwood. While we remain cautious in the near
term, we raise our long-term pulp price forecast to
$680/t (from $635/t) as supply-demand looks more
balanced from 2019.

BE11:57am

Packaging margin recovery delayed

11:57 am
BE11:57am

The combination of rapidly rising container board
prices and an upward trend in OCC prices is
weighing on both integrated and non-integrated box
producers’ margins. While we continue to model
box price increases for 2H17 and into 2018, higher
raw material costs imply a longer path to margin
recovery and somewhat smaller potential for margin
expansion than we previously expected. We thus
have a more balanced outlook on packaging.

BE11:59am

So ...... take profit into the start-of-year price hikes we were on about over Christmas, when there's nothing else to write about beyond annual negotiations for kraftliner supplies.

BE11:59am

Stora is up 11% ytd, driven by higher pulp prices
and a solid ramp-up of its Chinese Behai mill. While
we expect the Chinese ramp-up to remain on track,
we believe negative pulp price momentum will
weigh on Stora in the near term, and reiterate our
Sell (13% downside potential). Smurfit is up 27%
ytd, outperforming our P&P coverage by 14% and
the broader market by 22%. We downgrade the
stock to Neutral from Buy post outperformance.
